The Devil is in the Sources! Knowledge Enhanced Cross-Domain
Recommendation in an Information Bottleneck Perspective

Binbin Hu bin.hbb@antfin.com Ant GroupChinaHangzhou ,  Weifan Wang weifan.wwf@antgroup.com Ant GroupChinaHangzhou ,  Shuhan Wang hanshu.wsh@antgroup.com Ant GroupChinaHangzhou ,  Ziqi Liu ziqiliu@antgroup.com Ant GroupChinaHangzhou ,  Bin Shen ringo.sb@antgroup.com Ant GroupChinaHangzhou ,  Yong He heyong.h@antgroup.com Ant GroupChinaHangzhou  and  Jiawei Chen sleepyhunt@zju.edu.cn Zhejiang UniversityChinaHangzhou
(2024)
Abstract.

Cross-domain Recommendation (CDR) aims to alleviate the data sparsity and the cold-start problems in traditional recommender systems by leveraging knowledge from an informative source domain. However, previously proposed CDR models pursue an imprudent assumption that the entire information from the source domain is equally contributed to the target domain, neglecting the evil part that is completely irrelevant to users’ intrinsic interest. To address this concern, in this paper, we propose a novel knowledge enhanced cross-domain recommendation framework named CoTrans, which remolds the core procedures of CDR models with: Compression on the knowledge from the source domain and Transfer of the purity to the target domain. Specifically, following the theory of Graph Information Bottleneck, CoTrans first compresses the source behaviors with the perception of information from the target domain. Then to preserve all the important information for the CDR task, the feedback signals from both domains are utilized to promote the effectiveness of the transfer procedure. Additionally, a knowledge-enhanced encoder is employed to narrow gaps caused by the non-overlapped items across separate domains. Comprehensive experiments on three widely used cross-domain datasets demonstrate that CoTrans significantly outperforms both single-domain and state-of-the-art cross-domain recommendation approaches.

Cross-domain recommendation, Information bottleneck, Graph neural network

1. Introduction

To alleviate information overload on the web and understand user preferences, recommender systems have become the key component for online marketplaces and achieved great success. Over the past decades, a variety of strategies have been developed to harness users’ historical behaviors to enhance the quality of recommendation, ranging from traditional collaborative filtering (Linden et al., 2003; Sarwar et al., 2001) and deep neural networks (He et al., 2017) to sequential modeling (Lei et al., 2021) and graph learning (Liu et al., 2021a; Guo et al., 2021a). Despite the advancements, recommender systems still grapple with the issues of data sparsity and the cold-start problem, significantly hindering the ability to capture user interests accurately and efficiently.

To address these headaches, researchers have recently resorted to the Cross-Domain Recommendation (CDR) that effectively transfers knowledge from informative scenarios (source domain) to improve the learning process of poor scenarios with sparse interactions (target domain). Earlier work (Zhao et al., 2023; Liu et al., 2021b; Zhu et al., 2019) aims at learning shared knowledge through embedding-level mapping and alignment across different domains, followed by a multi-task learning paradigm. However, these methods commonly learn a unified mapping function shared by all users through a shallow architecture, thus resulting in inflexible representation transferring. Further, more advanced architectures are proposed to establish correlations across different domains for more precise recommendations. In particular, recent approaches towards CDR mainly focus on the following three aspects: i) fine-grained sequential pattern transferring (Li et al., 2022; Ma et al., 2022) via a deep attention mechanism ii) effectively characterizing user-specific preference in CDR with meta-learning (Zhu et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2022) and iii) flexibly incorporating rich auxiliary information (e.g., taxonomy) into CDR with graph learning (Liu et al., 2020; Zhao et al., 2019; Guo et al., 2021b) and contrastive learning (Yi et al., 2023; Cao et al., 2022a). Although substantial advancements have been made, most of them commonly overlook such an essential question “For each user, does all knowledge from source domains deserve being transferred ?”

Generally, most methods tailored for CDR assume that the entirety of information from the source domain is equally potential to be beneficial to the target domain. Unfortunately, it may not hold in most scenarios, especially for complex real-world applications, as interactions (e.g., click or purchase) of a certain user towards items are not completely motivated by his/her interests. Taking Fig. 1 as an example, although a user has purchased two books, it is possible that only the science fiction genre truly aligns with his genuine interests. This suggests that not all behavior history is reflective of users’ actual preferences, even contaminated with extraneous noise stemming from accidental clicks or other non-intentional actions (Wang et al., 2021; Gao et al., 2022). Subsequently, blindly fitting the observational behavior data in the source domains without considering the inherent correlation with target domains may seriously deteriorate the effectiveness of CDR, as illustrated in the upper part of Fig. 1.

To tackle this challenge, we aim to harness abundant behaviors from source domains to facilitate preference learning in target domains upon graph neural network architecture in a more principled way. That is, we anatomize the procedure of CDR into two subtasks: Compression and Transfer. Specifically, as shown in the bottom part of Fig. 1, our workflow adaptively discard target-irrelevant behaviors from the source “Book”domain (i.e., Compression) and preserve the core knowledge for the recommendation of the target “Movie” domain (i.e., Transfer). We borrow the main idea of graph information bottleneck theory (Wu et al., 2020; Tishby et al., 2000) (GIB) due to its ability to extract the minimum sufficient information — which is closely aligned with the goal of CDR to maintain the efficient and relevant information flow from source to target domains. Although the graph information bottleneck holds great potential for enhancing CDR tasks, the solution is quite challenging. Firstly, the identification of important and relevant user behaviors in the source domain is inherently dependent on their behaviors within target domains, highlighting the necessity for the Compression process to incorporate considerations of the target domain-specific contexts. Furthermore, in many scenarios, distinct domains may not have overlapping items (Liu et al., 2020; Han et al., 2023), potentailly leading to completely different item feature space. Bridging this content gap is essential for enabling effective Transfer.

To this end, we propose an innovative knowledge enhanced cross-domain recommendation framework CoTrans that effectively Compresses important information in source domains and then Transfers to the target domains. For the Compression process, we creatively leverage the users’ behaviors in the target domains to guide the graph information bottleneck, allowing the procedure to efficiently identify and prioritize information that is essential for the target domain. As for the process of Transfer, the purified source information, together with information from the target domain, contribute to the prediction task in both domains. Thus, more robust decisions could be made for the recommendation. Besides, the content gap arising from non-overlapping items between distinct domains significantly hampers effective knowledge integration during both the Compression and Transfer processes. We have empirically validated this assertion (see Section 4.3) — without an intermediary to facilitate knowledge propagation between domains, attempting to directly transfer knowledge from one domain to another could be ineffective or even harmful. To eliminate the knowledge isolation between domains, we introduce an open-sourced Knowledge Graph (Bordes et al., 2013) to infer the item embedding, serving as a bridge for effective knowledge propagation.

We summarize our main contributions as follows: i) We reformulate the CDR task from the perspective of the Information Bottleneck and propose an innovative paradigm for CDR task, i.e., Compression and Transfer. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first effort to reveal the intrinsic of CDR task from the GIB perspective with full consideration of behaviors in target domains. ii) We introduce a knowledge enhanced encoder, which employs a knowledge graph (KG) as the intermediary between different domains, thus overcoming the information heterogeneity between different domains that hinders knowledge propagation. iii) We compare CoTrans to extensive algorithms including both single-domain and cross-domain recommenders, achieving significant improvements on all CDR datasets.

2. Preliminary

2.2. Information Bottleneck

Learned from information theory, the identification of relevant information to retain and irrelevant information to discard from input data holds significance. The information bottleneck (IB) theory (Tishby et al., 2000) offers a systematic and principled framework to address this challenge. By compressing the source random variable, IB aims to retain the information essential for accurately predicting the target random variable while disregarding any information that is not relevant to the target variable.

Definition 0.

Informantion Bottleneck. Given the original data 𝐗𝐗\bm{X}bold_italic_X with label 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y}bold_Y, IB is to obtain a compact and effective representation 𝐙𝐙\bm{Z}bold_italic_Z of 𝐗𝐗\bm{X}bold_italic_X. The objective of the IB principle is as follows:

(1) m⁢i⁢n𝒁−I⁢(𝐘;𝒁)+β⁢I⁢(𝑿;𝒁),subscript𝑚𝑖𝑛𝒁𝐼𝐘𝒁𝛽𝐼𝑿𝒁\mathop{min}\limits_{\bm{Z}}-I(\mathbf{Y};\bm{Z})+\beta I(\bm{X};\bm{Z}),start_BIGOP italic_m italic_i italic_n end_BIGOP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_I ( bold_Y ; bold_italic_Z ) + italic_β italic_I ( bold_italic_X ; bold_italic_Z ) ,

where I⁢(⋅;⋅)𝐼⋅⋅I(\cdot;\cdot)italic_I ( ⋅ ; ⋅ ) denotes the mutual information of two random variables, β𝛽\betaitalic_β is a Lagrangian multiplier for balancing the two terms.

Recently, the information bottleneck principle has also been employed to learn an essential and minimal graph structure.

Definition 0.

Graph Information Bottleneck. Given a graph 𝒢={𝒱,ℰ}𝒢𝒱ℰ\mathcal{G}=\{\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}\}caligraphic_G = { caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E } and its label information 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y}bold_Y, the graph information principle aims at discovering the optimal graph 𝒢^={𝒱^,ℰ^}^𝒢^𝒱^ℰ\mathcal{\hat{G}}=\{\mathcal{\hat{V}},\mathcal{\hat{E}}\}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG = { over^ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG , over^ start_ARG caligraphic_E end_ARG } through:

(2) min𝒢^−I⁢(𝐘;𝒢^)+β⁢I⁢(𝒢;𝒢^),subscript^𝒢𝐼𝐘^𝒢𝛽𝐼𝒢^𝒢\mathop{\min}\limits_{\mathcal{\hat{G}}}-I(\mathbf{Y};\mathcal{\hat{G}})+\beta I% (\mathcal{G};\mathcal{\hat{G}}),roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_I ( bold_Y ; over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG ) + italic_β italic_I ( caligraphic_G ; over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG ) ,

where 𝒱^^𝒱\mathcal{\hat{V}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_V end_ARG and ℰ^^ℰ\mathcal{\hat{E}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_E end_ARG represent the task-relevant set of nodes and edges of the original graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G respectively.

3. Methodology

In this section, we present our proposed approach CoTrans, an innovative cross-domain recommendation framework guided by the graph information bottleneck that Compresses and then Transfers user preference from source domains to facilitate the recommendation performance in target domains.

3.1. Cross-domain Recommendation under Graph Information Bottleneck

We first reformulate the CDR task from the perspective of the graph information bottleneck and then demystify the underlying reasons.

3.1.1. Formulation

In our study, we are interested in learning the core behavior sub-graph of a user from the source domain 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S with the careful consideration of his/her interactions in the target domain 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T, which efficiently encapsulates user preference within source domains, ensuring that only the most relevant and impactful knowledge is retained. Consequently, we establish the fundamental bridge between the graph information bottleneck and CDR as follows:

Definition 0.

Graph Information Bottleneck Towards CDR. Given a user’s behavior graph 𝒢𝒮superscript𝒢𝒮\mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and feedback matrix 𝐘𝒮superscript𝐘𝒮\mathbf{Y}^{\mathcal{S}}bold_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the source domain 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S, paired with his/her behavior graph 𝒢𝒯superscript𝒢𝒯\mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{T}}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐘𝒯superscript𝐘𝒯\mathbf{Y}^{\mathcal{T}}bold_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in target domain 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T, our goal is to obtain most relevant/important behaviors towards target domains, denoted as 𝒢^𝒮|𝒯superscript^𝒢conditional𝒮𝒯\mathcal{\hat{G}}^{\mathcal{S}|\mathcal{T}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S | caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

(3) min𝒢^𝒮|𝒯β⁢I⁢(𝒢𝒮;𝒢^𝒮|𝒯|𝒢𝒯)⏟Compression⁢−I⁢(𝐘𝒯;𝒢^𝒮|𝒯|𝒢𝒯)−I⁢(𝐘𝒮;𝒢^𝒮|𝒯|𝒢𝒯)⏟Transfer.subscriptsuperscript^𝒢conditional𝒮𝒯subscript⏟𝛽𝐼superscript𝒢𝒮conditionalsuperscript^𝒢conditional𝒮𝒯superscript𝒢𝒯Compressionsubscript⏟𝐼superscript𝐘𝒯conditionalsuperscript^𝒢conditional𝒮𝒯superscript𝒢𝒯𝐼superscript𝐘𝒮conditionalsuperscript^𝒢conditional𝒮𝒯superscript𝒢𝒯Transfer\mathop{\min}_{\mathcal{\hat{G}}^{\mathcal{S}|\mathcal{T}}}\ \underbrace{\beta I% (\mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{S}};\mathcal{\hat{G}}^{\mathcal{S}|\mathcal{T}}|% \mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{T}})}_{\textit{Compression}}\underbrace{-I(\mathbf{Y}^{% \mathcal{T}};\mathcal{\hat{G}}^{\mathcal{S}|\mathcal{T}}|\mathcal{G}^{\mathcal% {T}})-I({\mathbf{Y}}^{\mathcal{S}};\mathcal{\hat{G}}^{\mathcal{S}|\mathcal{T}}% |\mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{T}})}_{\textit{Transfer}}.roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S | caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under⏟ start_ARG italic_β italic_I ( caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S | caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Compression end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under⏟ start_ARG - italic_I ( bold_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S | caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_I ( bold_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S | caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Transfer end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Intuitively, in the settings of CDR, the graph information bottleneck aims to learn the core behavior of the source domains via the following Compression and Transfer procedures:

  • •

    We introduce the users’ behaviors in the target domains into the information bottleneck for a more rational compression, allowing our framework to prioritize information that is essential for the target domain. In particular, guided by signals in the target domains, target-irrelevant information from the source domains is efficiently discarded by minimizing the term I⁢(𝒢𝒮;𝒢^𝒮|𝒯|𝒢𝒯)𝐼superscript𝒢𝒮conditionalsuperscript^𝒢conditional𝒮𝒯superscript𝒢𝒯I(\mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{S}};\mathcal{\hat{G}}^{\mathcal{S}|\mathcal{T}}|% \mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{T}})italic_I ( caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; over^ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S | caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

  • •

    In the settings of CDR, signals pertinent to the recommendation task should be effectively maintained across both the source and target domains since the efficacy of the CDR system hinges on its ability to leverage informative cues from one domain to enhance its predictions in another. 3.1.2. Why it works ?

The innovative formulation allows us to examine the CDR task through the lens of information theory, potentially inducing a robust approach that is resilient against noise and superfluous structures within real-world recommender systems. In particular, we provide a theoretical guarantee as follows:

Lemma 0.

Given a pair of behavior graphs (𝒢𝒮,𝒢𝒯)superscript𝒢𝒮superscript𝒢𝒯(\mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{S}},\mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{T}})( caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for both domains and corresponding feedback matrix {𝐘𝒮,𝐘𝒯}superscript𝐘𝒮superscript𝐘𝒯\{\mathbf{Y}^{\mathcal{S}},\mathbf{Y}^{\mathcal{T}}\}{ bold_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, let 𝒢~𝒮superscript~𝒢𝒮\mathcal{\tilde{G}}^{\mathcal{S}}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_G end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represent users’ redundant behaviors in the source domain that are irrelevant to their true preference. Then the following inequality holds:

Hence, it provides a theoretical guarantee that our formulation leads to the noise invariance property for CDR by discarding the information from the source domains that have no benefit to the final recommendation task in the target domain. A detailed proof is given in Appendix A.1.

3.2. Instantiation of CoTrans

To this end, the reformed CoTrans under Graph Information Bottleneck has provided a novel and advanced solution for CDR: (1) CoTrans operates a customized compression upon information in the source domain, enabled by discerning personal behaviors in the target domain. (2) CoTrans promises a stable knowledge transfer by preserving the task-relevant signal in both domains. As a whole, the engagement of compressed source information also vouches for a more controllable transfer procedure. In this section, we will give a deeper insight into CoTrans and detail how it works to operate the compression and transfer procedures. Specifically, we first introduce the knowledge-enhanced encoder that eliminates the isolation between distinct domains. Subsequently, we will instantiate the compression and transfer procedures of CoTrans, and reveal the mechanism behind them.

3.2.1. Knowledge-enhanced Encoder.

As mentioned in Section 1, the information in the source domain cannot directly serve the target recommendation, since the items are not shared between the source and target domains, causing the distributions of aggregated representations from distinct domains not compatible. To overcome this problem, we design an easily deployed encoder to produce generalized representations by implanting a knowledge graph (KG) with entity set ℬℬ\mathcal{B}caligraphic_B between distinct domains. 3.2.2. Instantiation of Compression.

3.2.3. Instantiation of Transfer.

To transfer the exquisite knowledge from the compressor into the target domain for superior recommendation, the rest two terms in Eq. (3) need to be minimized jointly. The proof for Eq (9) will be detailed in Appendix A.2.

Up to now, we have gained a profound see into the mechanism of CoTrans. Given an airscape upon the whole model, we observe that CoTrans strives to perform a careful knowledge compression and transfer for the CDR task. The perspective of the graph information bottleneck also supplies a decomposition to the CDR task and assists the recommender in making more sensible decisions.

3.3. Optimization of CoTrans

In this section, we detail the optimization for each part of CoTrans.

3.3.1. Optimization for Compression.

Remark 2.

The compression process takes an implicit way to obtain the optimal representations of the sub-structure of source domains, without explicitly probing into what the structure looks like. It could work well as the representation learning has already preserved the property of the optimal sub-structure, meanwhile ensuring the high efficiency of CoTrans.

4. Experiment

4.1. Experimental Settings

4.1.1. Datasets and Evaluation Metrics

In this section, we construct three pairs of cross-domain recommendation datasets including Amazon Movies (AM) & Amazon Books (AB), Amazon Movies (AM) & Amazon CDs (AC), and Amazon Books (AB) & Amazon CDs (AC). For each pair of CDR datasets, the users are fully overlapped and we conduct the CDR task in both directions for all the methods. A detailed description of the datasets is given in Table  2. Considering the knowledge graph, we employ Freebase 111https://developers.google.com/freebase., an online knowledge base containing massively structured triples, and extract a sub-graph from it with the entities linked by items that exist in all the CDR datasets as seeds to reduce computing costs. Specifically, the sub-KG contains 3,599,000 entities with 32,796,605 edges and is planted into each pair of CDR datasets utilized in this paper.

To evaluate the recommendation performance of our CoTrans and other baseline approaches, we follow previous works (Zhuo et al., 2022) and adopt the ranking-based evaluation strategy, i.e., leave-one-out evaluation. Specifically, for each user, we randomly select two historical interactions from the target dataset, one for validation, and the other for testing. The rest of the dataset is regarded as the training set. The validation and test sets are shared for all models to ensure fair evaluations. For each pair of datasets, we only keep users with more than three historical interactions in both domains.

4.1.2. Competitors

To verify the effectiveness of CoTrans, we compare with both single- and cross-domain recommendation models. We first select NMF (He et al., 2017) and LightGCN (He et al., 2020), two classical approaches for single-domain recommendations as the most straight baselines. As for the cross-domain recommenders, we compare against TIGER (Zhuo et al., 2022), DTCDR (Zhu et al., 2019), GA-DTCDR (Zhu et al., 2020), CCDR (Xie et al., 2022) and DDTCDR (Li and Tuzhilin, 2020). Note that TIGER is a CDR approach tailored for the cold-start scenario and we implement it on an oracle setting, i.e., the model is trained on the training set of the target domain. Besides, we additionally compare with another model that also incorporates an information bottleneck in the CDR task, called CDRIB (Cao et al., 2022b).

4.1.3. Implement Details.

Our framework is implemented using Pytorch. The embedding size for all representations is 32. We take Adagrad (Duchi et al., 2011) with the initial learning rate 1e-3 for model optimization. For all the methods, we set the batch size to 4096 and the training maximum epoch to 100. As for the set of hyper-parameters 𝜶={α1,α2,α3}𝜶subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2subscript𝛼3\bm{\alpha}=\{\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\alpha_{3}\}bold_italic_α = { italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } involved in Eq (16), we employ a grid search with an early stop strategy on NDCG@100 of the validation set to determine the best configuration. Table 3 gives the settings of (α1,α2,α3)subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2subscript𝛼3(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\alpha_{3})( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on each pair of CDR datsets. To ensure a fair comparison, all GNN-engaged CDR models apply the LightGCN as the backbone with the same structure, such as the number of layers. To match an entity for each item, we feed the title of the item into the API released by Google 222https://developers.google.com/knowledge-graph., then the API returns the top-K relevant entities and we choose the first one as the corresponding entity. Note that the extra computation cost introduced by Cotrans is O⁢(2⁢|V|⁢d2)𝑂2𝑉superscript𝑑2O(2|V|d^{2})italic_O ( 2 | italic_V | italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), which is linear to the number of nodes, making it possible for efficient inference for a real-world recommender system.

4.2. Performance Comparison

Table 1 reports the performance of the three CDR datasets. Note that we conduct the CDR task on each dataset in a bidirectional setting, i.e., the role of each sub-dataset would be switched between the target domain and source domain. We have several observations:

Comparison with Single-Domain Models: (1) For single-domain methods, we observe that the GNN-based methods LightGCN consistently outperform NMF, which validates that the high-order information of collaborative filtering plays a key role in recommendations. (2) CoTrans significantly and consistently outperforms LightGCN by a considerable margin across all the metrics of all the datasets. This indicates that the single-domain methods cannot make the optimal decision on the recommendation in the target domain without leveraging useful knowledge from other domains.

Comparison with Cross-Domain Models: (1) Among the cross-domain methods, CoTrans achieves the best performance in most cases. Such an encouraging performance gain indicates that CoTrans could make a more elegant transfer of the knowledge from the source domain into the target recommendation task, which is achieved by both the adoption of the general KG knowledge for gap mitigation between different domains and the adaptive source behavior compression conditioned on target knowledge.

CDR is Not Always Worked: We surprisingly find that sometimes LightGCN could outperform CDR approaches by a large margin, which demonstrates that an inappropriate transfer of source knowledge might cause a negative influence on recommendation tasks in the target domain. This emphasizes a delicate behavior compression and transfer mechanism designed for the CDR task is necessary.

4.3. Ablation Study

To verify the benefit of the conditional compression module of our model, we first prepare four variants of CoTrans: i) CoTrans without the objective ℒp⁢r⁢e⁢d𝒮superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑝𝑟𝑒𝑑𝒮\mathcal{L}_{pred}^{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_r italic_e italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is blind to the label information from the source domain. ii) CoTrans without the objective ℒK⁢Lsubscriptℒ𝐾𝐿\mathcal{L}_{KL}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which loses the ability of compression for user behaviors in the source domain. iii) CoTrans without the objective ℒC⁢Lsubscriptℒ𝐶𝐿\mathcal{L}_{CL}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which ignores the relevance between the compressed user behaviors in the source domain and his portrait in the target domain. iiii) Besides, to estimate the necessity of KG incorporation for breaking the item isolation mentioned in Secion 1, we additionally run a full version of CoTrans with simple ID-embedding initialization on the item side, which is completely irrelevant between distinct domains. Due to the space limitation, we only report the experimental results on AM&AB dataset in both directions.

The results in Figure 3 show that ignoring any module is not ideal, from which we have the following conclusions: i) Label information from both domains is necessary for the final recommendation task. ii) Knowledge compression for user behaviors in the source domain can promise the most relevant information to be transferred into the target domain. iii) It is also essential to retain the reliable portrait of users derived from their behavior in the target domain. iiii) Removing the intermediary that eliminates the isolation between separate domains would significantly harm the model performance. In a word, each objective could assist the models in conducting more elaborate knowledge compression and transfer, subsequently enhancing the performance on downstream tasks. Similar results are observed in other datasets.

4.4. Sensitive Analysis

As mentioned above, CoTrans involves several important hyper-parameters, i.e., balance factors α1,α2subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and α3subscript𝛼3\alpha_{3}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eq. (16). Here, we investigate the impact of these parameters on the grid search strategy. Due to space limitations, we just report the results on AM&AB dataset in both directions.

From Fig. 4 we find: i) CoTrans usually achieves the worst performance when any parameter of {α1,α2\{\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2}{ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,α3}\alpha_{3}\}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is set to zero, demonstrating the indispensability of each module of CoTrans. ii) Large α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT causes apparent performance degradation, indicating that overreliance on the knowledge from the source domain is not encouraged and a trade-off between knowledge from different domains should be made. Similar results are observed in other datasets.

4.5. Robustness Analysis

To verify CoTrans’s robustness to the redundant interaction noises that existed in the source domain, we generate different proportions of negative interactions (i.e., 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%) to contaminate the behavior graph in the source domain, and report the performance on the test set. Besides, we chose CCDR and DDTCDR, two baselines that showed competitive performance in Section 4.2 into the analysis. Figure 5 shows the results on Amazon-Book (Source) and Amazon-Movie (Target), and the performance degradation ratio of the corresponding contaminated ratio. It’s obvious that the more noise added to the source behavior, the worse performance all the models yield. However, the performance degradation of CoTrans is smoother and smaller than other approaches. Specifically, from the left sub-figure of Figure 5, when the noise ratio is small (from 0 to 0.1), the performance degradation of CoTrans and CCDR is almost the same, however, when further enlarging the ratio, the gap between CoTrans and CCDR grows larger. These observations imply that CoTrans is robust to the noise that exists in the users’ source behaviors, making it possible to concentrate on the most relevant source behaviors with the target recommendation task.

5. Related Work

5.1. Cross-Domain Recommendation

CDR is supposed to solve the data sparsity problem that has confused recommender systems a lot by transferring knowledge across separate domains. Earlier work mainly solved this issue based on MF and its extension (Hu et al., 2018; Zhu et al., 2022; Lian et al., 2017; Hu et al., 2013). In recent years, many more techniques have been employed in the CDR task including but not limited to meta-learning, graph learning, contrastive learning (Zhu et al., 2020; Xie et al., 2022; Tian et al., 2024), etc. To name a few, GA-DTCDR (Zhu et al., 2020) first constructs two separate heterogeneous graphs from two domains and employs an element-wise attention mechanism to combine the embeddings of common users learned from both domains, thus improving the recommendation accuracy on each domain.

Despite their success, most CDR methods hold that the entirety of information from the source domain is equally beneficial to the target recommendation task, and should be preserved and transferred. However, as we discussed in Section 1, it is inevitable for a user to interact with items that are not completely relevant to his/her internet interests. It would be evil to the target recommendation if such inadvertent and random behaviors are transferred into the target domain.

5.2. Graph Information Bottleneck

Recently, many works (Wu et al., 2020; Yu et al., 2020, 2022a; Wei et al., 2022) have proposed to extend the basic Information Bottleneck into graph data and generate a new branch of information theory named Graph Information Bottleneck (GIB), which has been widely applied to quite a few tasks. For instance, GIB (Yu et al., 2020) utilizes IB to regularize the structural information in the node classification task. It employs the Shannon mutual information to measure how compressed and informative the subgraph distribution is. CDRIB (Cao et al., 2022b) is the only attempt that applies a vanilla information bottleneck (IB) approach to CDR. However, this method just heuristically imposes the IB principle on the CDR scenario and the causality between the CDR task and IB theory is still a mystery. Besides, CDRIB ignores users’ target behaviors when optimizing the term for information minimality, whereas our CoTrans  defines a graph information bottleneck (CIB) for the CDR task, which incorporates target domain information as a condition when evaluating relevance. This target domain information is crucial in CDR, as it guides the extraction of relevant information from the source domain for transfer.

In summary, to the best of our knowledge, we are the first work that reveals the intrinsic mechanism of CDR tasks under a Graph Information Bottleneck perspective. Moreover, the concretized procedures of Compression and Transfer make the CDR task easier to operate and be reformed for future study on this topic.

6. Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed the framework CoTrans for the CDR task, which represents an attempt to Compresse valuable sub-structure in source domains and then Transfers to the target domain. In particular, following the theory of Graph Information Bottleneck, we operate the compression on the source behaviors with the perception of information from the target domain. Then to preserve all the task-relevant information during the procedure of transfer, we utilize the feedback signals from both domains for a more robust transfer of knowledge. Besides, we employ a knowledge-enhanced encoder to narrow the gap between distinct domains and facilitate knowledge integration during both procedures of compression and transfer. The extensive experiments conducted on three public datasets verify the effectiveness of CoTrans.

Limitation As demonstrated in Section 3.3.1, current CoTrans could compress the source behaviors by estimating the reliability of users’ integrated representations. Overall, the compression in the CoTrans pipeline is built on the representation level (i.e., directly embeds the optimal sub-structure into an embedding), which may lack of intuitive interpretability. Obviously, more sophisticated compression might be achieved such as directly operating upon the structure of behavior graph 𝒢𝒮superscript𝒢𝒮\mathcal{G}^{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which we leave as a future work.
